awd_titl_txt: SusCHEM: Fundamental Studies on Lyopreservation of Adult Stem Cells
awd_abstract_narration:
1605425 
He, Xiaoming  

Lyopreservation of living cells for banking in a state of suspended animation at ambient temperature makes it possible to achieve low-cost maintenance and convenient distribution of the cells.   The ready availability of cells is crucial for the wide application and eventual success of cell-based therapies involving tissue engineering, regenerative medicine, cell transplantation, blood transfusion, and stem cell therapy. The objective of this project is to perform a systematic investigation to understand the protective effect of trehalose, a nontoxic sugar, during freezing and drying of trehalose-laden human adipose-derived stem cells (hADSCs) and in banking the dried cells at ambient temperature. As trehalose has been used for many lower organisms to survive extreme cold and drought in nature, it is hypothesized that trehalose-laden stem cells will behave similarly.  

This project will have a significant impact on improving healthcare by facilitating the development of cell lyopreservation as an enabling technology for the success of cell-based medical treatments. The use of a nontoxic sugar (trehalose) to replace toxic chemicals (e.g., dimethyl sulfoxide or DMSO) for cell banking is well aligned with the NSF SusCHEM initiative to replace toxic chemicals with earth-abundant, inexpensive, and benign materials. To understand the fundamental science of drying living cells for banking in a state of suspended animation at ambient temperature, three specific research tasks are proposed. These include  (i) investigation of the effect of freeze-drying parameters on the kinetics of drying trehalose solutions important for lyopreservation of primary hADSCs and on the microscopic morphology of the dried products, using freeze-drying microscopy and a benchtop freeze-dryer for small and large samples, respectively; (ii) simulation and experimental quantification of the biophysical responses of the trehalose-laden hADSCs to freezing and drying including cell dehydration and intracellular ice formation important for cell survival; and (iii) analysis of the morphology, survival, long-term proliferation, and stem cell properties and functions of the primary hADSCs after freeze-drying and banking at ambient temperature. The stem cell properties and functions will be assessed by the expression of stem cell gene and protein markers and their capability of adipogenic, osteogenic, and chondrogenic differentiation. A high survival and intact function of the primary hADSCs are anticipated after freeze-drying and long-term storage at ambient temperature under optimal conditions.
This award by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division is cosponsored by the Biomaterials Program of the Division of Materials Research.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Contemporary methods for banking living cells requires the use of both cryogenic temperature like that of liquid nitrogen and toxic chemicals like dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO). This research seeks to achieve banking of living cells using a nontoxic agent (i.e., trehalose, a disaccharide of glucose), which has been synthesized by plants and lower organisms in nature in response to extreme cold/freezing and dry for them to survive at ambient temperature. However, mammalian cells do not have a mechanism to synthesize trehalose endogenously while trehalose is needed both inside and outside living cells for them to survive freezing and drying (i.e., freeze-drying or lyophilization) at ambient temperature. With the support of this project, we have been working on addressing the challenges facing lyopreservation (banking by freezing and drying) of living cells. 

Intellectual Merit: We have successfully developed a cold-response nanoparticle (CRNP) to encapsulate trehalose for its intracellular delivery. The trehalose-laden CRNPs can be efficiently taken up by various mammalian cells including adult stem cells. Furthermore, upon a short cold treatment at 4 ?C, which is a natural step of lyopreservation or cryopreservation, the CRNPs can rapidly release the encapsulated trehalose inside cells so that the sugar can protect the intracellular lipids, proteins, and subcellular organelles. Indeed, trehalose delivered by the CRNPs is shown to protect various mammalian cells including adult stem cells during freezing to maintain a high viability after warming them back, without the use of any toxic chemicals like DMSO. Moreover, the intracellular trehalose delivered using the CRNPs is shown to enhance the drying/desiccation tolerance of cumulus-oocyte-complex, indicating the great potential of achieving lyopreservation of living mammalian cells for banking them at ambient temperature.

Broader Impacts: The capability of banking living mammalian cells at ambient temperature enabled by the cold responsive technology developed by us, is valuable to the advancement of the burgeoning cell-based medicine. This is because the eventual success of the cell-based medicine relies upon banking living cells for convenient wide distribution and ready availability to end users at ambient temperature, just like that of pharmaceutical drugs today. Moreover, the proposed research was integrated into education through (a) incorporating the research findings into the biomaterials classes taught by the PI for both graduate and undergraduate students, (b) training a total of six graduate students (three women/minorities), seven undergraduates (five women/minorities), and one high school student (woman), and (c) disseminating the research findings via journal (12) and book chapter (1) publications, conference presentations (6), undergraduate honor?s theses (3), and the PI?s laboratory website.

 


Last Modified: 12/10/2022
Modified by: Xiaoming He
